speaker: ROMEO
content: Romeo asks how he can leave when his heart remains with Juliet. He tells his body to turn back and find its center, meaning his heart, then climbs the wall into the Capulet orchard.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio calls for Romeo, using 'cousin' here to mean kinsman or close friend.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio jokes that Romeo has sensibly stolen away home to bed.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio insists Romeo came this way and jumped the orchard wall, urging Mercutio to call for him.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio mockingly summons Romeo as if by magic, calling him by lover's traits and invoking Rosaline's features. He references Cupid and the tale of King Cophetua loving a beggar-maid, then declares Romeo must be dead to the world.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio warns that if Romeo hears this mocking, he will be angered.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio claims his conjuring won't anger Romeo, but summoning a spirit in his mistress's magical circle until she dismisses it would be an insult. He insists his own invocation is honest and meant only to call Romeo forth.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio suggests Romeo has hidden among the trees to keep company with the moody night, and that his blind love suits the darkness.

speaker: MERCUTIO
content: Mercutio puns that if love is blind, it cannot hit its target. He then makes a series of crude sexual jokes about medlar fruit, which was slang for female genitalia, and 'poperin pear' for the male, wishing Romeo and his mistress were such fruits. He concludes he is going to his trundle bed, finding the field too cold.

speaker: BENVOLIO
content: Benvolio agrees they should leave, since it is pointless to search for someone who does not wish to be found.
